content: What to say “No” to Hey Trevor Ewen, Great question. If I’m being perfectly honest I would say that I probably haven’t yet gotten far enough into the sabbatical for this to become a major problem since I haven’t had a lot of inbound requests. In terms of saying “no” to myself though — because let’s face it, that’s probably the most important thing — a few quick things I’ve found to be helpful so far: Forcing myself to articulate how something is working towards a broader goal of mine before doing it. Not just “is this aligned with my goals” but “what is the mechanism by which doing this helps me achieve my goal”. Sometimes I realize I can’t answer that question and then it gets dropped from the todo list.Time-boxing traps. I talked a little bit about this in the post, but if there is something you know has the potential to take you off course, but you think it might be valuable, you can at least time box it so you don’t invest too much into it.Prioritizing physical and mental health. A huge part of taking a sabbatical — for me at least — is recharging. So I try to do something specifically for health and happiness almost every day. This lets me do some of those things that are fun, interesting and beneficial and not have to worry about them being “productive” — I know I’m doing them for myself and my health and that makes them worthwhile.
